commit.message:
Add HDFile.readinto(length, out), re-implement read(...) in terms of readinto(...) (#162)

* HDFile.readinto(length, out), re-implement read in terms of readinto

also adds a new out_buffer parameter to read which allows better control
over the buffering behaviour

* make readinto work on python 2

turns out, python 2 memoryview doesn't have an nbytes attribute and also
can't construct ctypes types from memoryviews. we only used memoryviews
for a) being able to calculate the size, b) slicing, c) having
a consistent return type. so now we only convert in those places and
keep the original buffer around to pass it to ctypes.c_byte.from_buffer

* use reduce from functools to make flake8 happy

fix possible segmentation fault when connecting (#153)

* fix Segmentation fault on lastest libhdfs3

* Allow setting effective user

Plus, specify the type for the sedonc parameter to hdfsBuilderConnect

verification.payload:
tree bf15dc7dff711eba4046bcf8f80ea8bada8ad929
parent 3fd2c2739358d3326cf5cbc9ba979d2986386bc0

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1519753107 -0500

fix possible segmentation fault when connecting (#153)

* fix Segmentation fault on lastest libhdfs3

* Allow setting effective user

Plus, specify the type for the sedonc parameter to hdfsBuilderConnect

commit.message: Fix bug- overriding the buffer size at file read / write (#150)

Be more strict about unicode/bytes conversions (#147)

* Be more strict about unicode/bytes conversions

Previously this library relied upon duck-typed behavior, instead of
following precise schemas for the conversions between ctypes structs and
dictionaries of python objects. This led to unicode decode errors, as
bytestrings not representing human readable content were being decoded.

This fixes this issue in the following ways:

- Add `to_dict` methods to each relevant struct class that knows exactly
which fields are bytes and which are strings, and handles all
conversions appropriately.
- Make `ensure_bytes` and `ensure_string` more strict in terms of input
and output.

* fileds -> fields

verification.payload:
tree 84243dd9c80e360bef7fa610e8bae0da6236293b
parent 264de723a224eed9fd8bcba595e2dae1425abb9a
author Jim Crist <jcrist@users.noreply.github.com> 1516659695 -0800
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1516659695 -0800

Be more strict about unicode/bytes conversions (#147)

* Be more strict about unicode/bytes conversions

Previously this library relied upon duck-typed behavior, instead of
following precise schemas for the conversions between ctypes structs and
dictionaries of python objects. This led to unicode decode errors, as
bytestrings not representing human readable content were being decoded.

This fixes this issue in the following ways:

- Add `to_dict` methods to each relevant struct class that knows exactly
which fields are bytes and which are strings, and handles all
conversions appropriately.
- Make `ensure_bytes` and `ensure_string` more strict in terms of input
and output.

commit.message:
Move dask integration to hdfs3  (#144)

* Move dask integration to hdfs3

Move the hdfs & dask integration out of `distributed.hdfs`. This removes
the need for managing hdfs infrastructure in the distributed tests.

Also adds a pyarrow wrapper to support reading from hdfs using pyarrow.

Move dask integration to hdfs3  (#144)

* Move dask integration to hdfs3

Move the hdfs & dask integration out of `distributed.hdfs`. This removes
the need for managing hdfs infrastructure in the distributed tests.

Also adds a pyarrow wrapper to support reading from hdfs using pyarrow.

commit.message:
Cleanup CI (#143)

- Use pre-built docker image uploaded to docker-hub
- Cleanup docker file to give smaller image
- Cleanup environment scripts
- Don't sleep arbitrary amount of time, wait for hdfs to be setup
  properly using an indicator flag

commit.message:
Walk matches `os.walk` behavior (#141)

Currently this interface doesn't match the standard `os.walk` interface,
which returns an iterator of `dirname, dirs, files`. This fixes that,
and cleans up a few other methods that were using `walk`.

Walk matches `os.walk` behavior (#141)

Currently this interface doesn't match the standard `os.walk` interface,
which returns an iterator of `dirname, dirs, files`. This fixes that,
and cleans up a few other methods that were using `walk`.
